joke: Panamanian lawmakers’ Taiwan trip sparks diplomatic row with China, which is hilarious because most politicians can’t even manage a layover without causing a scandal, and now their frequent-flyer miles are more stable than their foreign policy.

Isn’t it funny how football clubs are like people at a sale—Carra says “Liverpool must sign in January - even after summer spending spree,” like they’ve just blown thousands on clothes and gone, “Yeah, but I don’t *feel* like a title contender yet.”
Experts warn of health threat posed by ultra-processed foods, which is shocking, because I always assumed the real danger was my gym membership automatically renewing.
Amazing how at Dick Cheney’s funeral, George W. Bush giving the eulogy still wasn’t the most uncomfortable thing Cheney ever made someone else do.

Isn’t it funny how in sports they say there’s "No place for Mostert distraction in South Africa team," like the real problem is one guy’s focus and not the 60 million armchair coaches yelling at their TVs in perfect tactical hindsight?

It’s funny how football fame works—“Meet Troy - the parrot named after Ireland’s hat-trick hero,” and now there’s a bird getting more interviews for screaming “OFFSIDE!” than most pundits do for explaining it.

Isn’t it funny that “Instagram to start closing Australian teen accounts ahead of social media ban” sounds less like a news headline and more like every parent’s dream excuse to finally say, “Sorry mate, it’s not me taking your phone—it’s government policy”?

They tried to regulate AI the way they regulate everything in the EU—by writing a 900‑page rulebook that no human can understand and then acting surprised when the only thing that can comply is the AI they were trying to control.

You ever notice how “Silent City” sounds peaceful until you stay in one of only two hotels in Malta’s Silent City and realize the silence is just you awkwardly whispering your complaints because everyone can hear everything?

Isn’t it funny how in Ireland, “bringing back Bundee Aki for clash with Springboks in Dublin” sounds less like a rugby decision and more like someone calling their toughest friend to help move a couch… that keeps tackling them?
Yes, it’s okay if you don’t love your partner all the time—modern relationships are 10% butterflies, 20% shared memes, and 70% politely not committing homicide while they chew loudly next to you.

Isn’t it funny how “Why footballer Troy Parrott is taking the classic Hero's Journey” sounds epic, but in modern football the big dragon he has to slay is just a really passive-aggressive post-match interview?
Apparently Gen Z are earning six figures as “professional quiet quitters,” which is where companies pay them consulting fees just to explain why no one wants a normal job anymore.

Isn’t it funny how in Hollywood you need “range” to be taken seriously, but when ‘Kim Kardashian had no pretensions that she was a great actress’: Glenn Close hits back at zero-star All’s Fair reviews, suddenly honesty gets worse ratings than the show?
Turns out “fibermaxxing” just means eating enough vegetables that your gut bacteria start writing you thank‑you notes and scheduling reasonable bathroom appointments.

Host Brazil said it’s pushing for progress on big issues at COP30, which is why negotiators were surprised to find the main proposal was just “teach cows to hold their breath.” Still, some see cause for optimism, because honestly, it’s the first climate plan that didn’t immediately get watered down—just slightly moo-ted.

Critic: “Oneohtrix Point Never’s Tranquilizer is uncanny ambient music for an agitated era.”  
Reader: “So it calms you down just enough to clearly understand how doomed everything is?”

I read “Advice from Whitty and Vallance on delaying lockdown ‘had no grounding in science’” and thought, “Wow, finally some experts operating at my level—I’ve been giving life advice with no grounding in science, finances, or basic common sense for years.”

Gaelic games reached such peak absurdity at the Asian Youth Championship in Hanoi that the referee had to pause the match to explain to a bewildered hurling stick that, no, it was not in fact a diplomatic envoy from Ireland but a piece of sports equipment participating in Vietnam.

It’s funny how in showbiz they say, “I made mistakes on TV, he made his on a field,” like that’s better—at least when I mess up, nobody has to watch the instant replay in slow motion with a telestrator circling my double chin.
Ottawa’s euthanized feral goldfish are being remembered in a brief ceremony, followed by a much longer moment of silence as officials pretend they didn’t just commit a glittery little genocide.
I told my partner I might not be cut out for non-monogamy, because every time they say they’re seeing other people, I can’t help wondering why I’m never their *type*.
I read "How Guinness World Records began 7 decades ago," and now I’m wondering if the first record was “Most people pretending to care about how Guinness World Records began 7 decades ago.”

Well, the UK’s Covid inquiry basically concluded the government’s pandemic plan was “too little, too late,” which is impressive, because that’s usually how their support arrives for nurses, renters, and literally anyone under 40.

The Dáil heard that thousands of people are “trapped” on the M7 every day, which is shocking—because with Irish public transport, most of us assumed being stuck in traffic was still the *fast* option.

Prada heir Lorenzo Bertelli becoming executive chairman at Versace is like your strict Italian dad running your cool cousin’s party—suddenly the glitter has a five-year strategic plan and even the sequins have performance reviews.
Miriam Toews: A loud voice in a town once ruled by silence—finally, a place where the librarian can shush someone and be accused of government overreach.
He collects pictures of old men’s faces for her, which is sweet until you realize he’s just prepping her for what he’ll look like after another season watching West Ham’s midfield die on the pitch.

Ninja just announced their dual zone air fryer hit its lowest price for Black Friday 2025, which is great news for everyone who’s been thinking, “I wish my kitchen appliance could sneak up on my frozen fries from two directions at once.”

After the "You're a disgrace': Dramatic scene as House avoids Rep. Cory Mills censure vote" headline, Congress clarified that they didn’t actually clear him—they just tabled the censure until they can invent a new punishment called “being forced to read your own quotes on C-SPAN for 12 hours straight.”
When picking a health care plan, the most important questions to ask are “What’s my deductible?” and “Does this cover the injuries I’ll get from stressing over what my deductible is?”

Nonalcoholic spirits go from strength to strength because after enough office parties, people realized they wanted to remember their bad decisions in HD instead of reconstructing them from blurry CCTV.
I took “Don’t trade where you tweet” as solid financial advice—so now I just lose money in complete silence, which feels much more professional.
Isn’t it funny that “Three-quarters of parents let children miss school for ‘duvet day’” but still call it “playing hooky,” when the kids are clearly majoring in Advanced Horizontal Studies?
Nasa releases new images of interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS, and astronomers say it’s truly groundbreaking—mainly because if it actually grounds, we’re all getting a surprise visit from space.

It’s funny how every “well-intentioned” stage adaptation of a grief novella just means you’ll spend two hours watching people cry under a bird-shaped light fixture while a director insists, “The feathers are a metaphor.”

“Polar vortex could bring wild weather pattern” — scientists say this week we should dress in layers, which is helpful, because I’ve always wondered how many coats it takes to admit you’ve lost the thermostat battle with your own house.

It’s funny how companies say AI is just a “helpful assistant,” but somehow the only thing it’s assisting with is making sure you’re doing three people’s jobs while politely asking it how to fight back.

I tried Alice Zaslavsky’s garlic red peppers with a creamy white bean dip, AKA papula, and now my friends think I’m sophisticated—joke’s on them, I only made it because it uses fewer dishes than ordering takeout.

In California, I’ve been writing about housing for more than a decade, which is ironic, because that’s also how long it takes here to realize your “starter home” is actually just your car with really strong manifesting skills.
Funny how David Muir reports on students learning sign language for a deaf therapy dog’s birthday, and suddenly every human relationship I’ve ever had looks under-celebrated.

Isn’t it weird how the SA Reserve Bank cuts the repo rate to 6.75 percent and every headline screams “what this means for your bond,” like my bank is suddenly going to say, “Surprise, we’ve decided you can keep your kidneys *and* your house this month”?

It’s funny that SpaceX launches second satellite to monitor sea level changes, as if the ocean were a teenager—“We checked once, but let’s send another satellite to make sure it’s not rolling its eyes and rising anyway.”
UK schools are closing for ‘Thundersnow’ and a cold snap, proving the weather now cancels plans faster than a group chat when someone suggests meeting before 9 a.m.
Border officials say the giant spider web found in the Greek-Albanian cave is the first truly effective immigration policy both countries have ever jointly enforced.
I wondered, "What is life like living permanently on board a cruise ship?"—turns out it’s just like my regular life, except now when I disappoint people, there’s a mandatory safety drill first.

“Black Friday deals for him that will make the perfect present” is funny, because nothing says “I love you” like a 70%‑off gadget he’ll use once while you quietly enjoy the fact that you saved more money than he thinks the gift cost.
You ever notice how when teachers say, “Group words that share a common thread,” it just turns into nouns forming little cliques while the verbs run around doing all the work?

Isn’t it funny how the Klamath becomes “America's largest river restoration project” only after humans mess it up first—like bragging about being the world champion at cleaning a kitchen you personally destroyed?

Isn’t it funny that the House passes bill to strip Senate phone investigations language from funding bill, when the only phone records Congress should really be worried about are the 47 missed calls from their constituents?

It’s funny how every country says “We did it!” when they qualify for the World Cup, as if the fans in their living rooms eating chips were out there running sprints instead of just yelling “SHOOT!” at the TV.

Isn’t it funny that the Princess of Wales says her children were “very sad” to miss Paddington at the Royal Variety show, when every other kid’s big disappointment is finding out the guy in the costume is just their sweaty PE teacher?
NASA unveils close-up pictures of interstellar comet 3I/Atlas, and scientists are stunned to discover it’s just a rock with “BRB, SWITCHING GALAXIES” carved into it in perfect English.

Every time I hear “This painting is the most expensive work of modern art ever sold at auction,” I wonder if the real masterpiece is the canvas—or the straight face of the person explaining why a blue square is “in dialogue with the human condition.”
Doing these fall garden chores will make your spring easier—because by then, the weeds will be so surprised you were responsible on time that they’ll be too intimidated to come back.

I just read “Owl rescued from concrete mixer now recovering in Utah” and thought, wow, that bird hit rock bottom and is already doing better than me—I willingly mix myself with bad decisions and still don’t have professionals rushing in to save me.

NYC foodies say, “What Mamdani's win means for NYC's food scene” is more vegan options and worker protections, but I’m just wondering when my $19 oat-milk latte will start campaigning for rent control.
Every Black Friday the best VPNs get reduced, which is fitting, because nothing says “online privacy” like proudly announcing to the world that you bought it on sale.

My therapist said, “You should be having more slumber parties with your friends,” which sounds fun until you realize it’s just a polite way of saying, “Your emotional issues now require a group project and matching pajamas.”

Helmsman, arrested for being on his phone when the ferry ran aground, insisted it wasn’t negligence because he was clearly on a call with “Customer Support for Reality” trying to download the latest map patch where the ocean has an undo button.

Despite record expansion and growing ambition in the continent, the US is surging ahead again—apparently the secret to staying number one is constantly warning everyone else about the dangers of ambition and expansion.

Isn’t it funny how Lily Allen can disappear for seven years, come back with "West End Girl" about heartbreak and healing, and we all call it “a brave artistic journey,” but if I vanish that long after a breakup it’s just my friends saying, “So… you gonna return my Tupperware or what?”

I read “Gambling probes halt lower leagues and suspend hundreds of players, but many say they are scapegoats,” and thought, “Wow, that’s exactly like my dating life—everyone claims they’re innocent, everything gets suspended, and somehow I’m still the only one who actually gets played.”

Sure—here’s the joke, in one short sentence:

“7 tips for getting to sleep during cold weather living: step one, stop checking the thermostat you can’t afford to turn up.”

Scientists calling kissing an “evolutionary conundrum” is hilarious—humans spent millennia perfecting the art of smooching, and only now do we have a map, as if some caveman once said, “I’m not kissing you unless there’s peer‑reviewed data.”
It’s funny that Anna Ansari’s cookbook is called *Silk Roads*, because whenever I try to recreate food from my travels, the only thing that actually transports me back is the food poisoning.
In times of sweeping change, clarity matters most—said every company right before sending a 47-page PDF explaining nothing.

I subscribed to "The World in Pictures Get The AP’s most compelling photographs sent directly to your inbox," but all I get is a daily close-up of my shocked face when I realize I’ve been staring at my email for four hours instead of living in the actual world.

It’s funny how Nvidia’s blowout earnings can launch a massive morning rally, and by the afternoon your portfolio looks like it bought tickets to the excitement and then left early to beat the traffic.

I just saw the "Moment a Gustav Klimt painting sells for record amount" and thought, “Wow, somebody just paid $100 million for something confusing and unfinished,” which is weird, because my ex got that from me for free.

Millennials are set to inherit tons of their parents' stuff — which is perfect, because nothing says “financial independence” like owning six china sets, three broken rocking chairs, and zero housing.

Apparently “World Cup 2026 playoffs draw: reaction and updates” is just football’s polite way of saying, “Here’s the exact moment half these countries start Googling what ‘mathematically still possible’ means.”
Inside the courtroom for Australia's biggest trials, the most shocking revelation was that everyone had already judged the case—except the jury.

Isn’t it funny how “US tech group’s quarterly sales outstrip expectations, reassuring investors and boosting shares worldwide” really just means some app convinced us to pay $14.99 a month to keep doing what we were already doing for free?

It’s funny that boomers think Gen Z and millennials are lazy for avoiding management, when “conscious unbossing” just means we finally realized every promotion is basically, “Congrats, here’s more emails and fewer boundaries—also, you’re responsible for Brad now.”
It’s funny that Abbott just paid $23 billion for the company that makes Cologuard, because only in American healthcare can a poop-in-a-box test be worth more than most entire hospitals.
At the funeral, George W. Bush said Dick Cheney always had his back—mostly because he was standing in front of him, taking all the shots.
Isn’t it funny that a Paris court blocks auction of earliest-known calculator, like even in 2026 we’re still trying to stop machines from doing the math on how much we’re worth?
I tried limiting my time online, but now I just spend twice as long googling “how to limit time online” and counting that as progress.

Isn’t it odd that “The AI Shift: Do we prefer talking to machines rather than each other?” sounds less like a tech headline and more like the moment you realize the chatbot actually listens, remembers your birthday, and doesn’t interrupt to tell you about its fantasy football league?
In Kentucky, "eating like a pro" just means realizing the bourbon on your ribs has a higher proof than anything you’ve ever made for dinner.

Therapists now recommend holding an ice cube and shaking like a dog to reduce stress, which is impressive progress when you realize the previous medical advice was just “be the reason other people need therapy.”
The Thanksgiving travel tips article said the worst day to fly is Wednesday and the worst day to drive is Sunday, which is helpful, because now I know the best day to travel is never.

“Students are protesting a course taught by AI, which is hilarious, because for the last five years every professor’s been reading PowerPoint slides from 2009 and we all just pretended it wasn’t already automated.”

It’s funny how cruise ads say “From cuisine and culture to history and nature, find the ideal cruise,” as if my ideal cruise isn’t just finding the one where I can eat unlimited shrimp without accidentally learning anything.
Isn’t it funny that a Frida Kahlo self-portrait is about to shatter auction records, while the best I can manage in the mirror is, “Wow, that’s a brave angle for my chin to choose today”?

LeBron James just started his 23rd NBA season playing against guys born after he debuted, which is inspiring—because apparently if you stick around long enough, “veteran leadership” is just code for “babysitting with a max contract.”
So the new wipes are fully flushable, biodegradable, and eco-certified—meaning the only thing we’re really testing is how long human plumbing can keep pretending it’s a marine ecosystem.
Everyone’s asking, “Ní thuigim: does AI even understand Gaeilge?” and I’m like, if it did, it would’ve run away already after being told “craic” is fun, “mad” is good, and “deadly” is a compliment.
Scientists are worried sea level rise will flood toxic sites, which is ironic, because apparently the ocean finally found a way to do an environmental impact statement on us.

They say history's "most controversial" queen was so hated because of her ruthless politics, but actually it started when she replaced the royal decree with a group chat and kept reacting “LOL” every time a neighboring kingdom declared war.
What you can do in your 30s to stay healthy at 70: start saving now so you can afford all the wellness gadgets that promise to fix the damage you’re doing in your 30s.

Thousands of US hazardous sites are at risk of flooding from sea level rise, which is exciting because for the first time in history the ocean is coming to us for our chemicals instead of us dumping them in.

When I saw the headline “The Nazis on trial: The enduring lessons of Nuremberg, 80 years on,” I thought, “Wow, history really teaches accountability”… then remembered I still blame my group projects on ‘circumstances beyond my control.’

Isn’t it funny how every article asks, “Is modular construction the answer to the housing crisis,” like the real problem isn’t zoning or prices, it’s that we forgot to click “add extra bedroom” at checkout?
Las Vegas police are asking for the public’s help finding a casino armed robbery suspect, which is weird, because I thought the house always wins—except, apparently, at background checks.

They saw Claire Danes grieving in *The Beast in Me* and thought, “Sure, my therapist charges $200 an hour to emotionally wreck me, but at least HBO throws in a free trauma subplot and better lighting.”
Liverpool chairman opens up on contract talks with Salah and Van Dijk: “We’ve agreed Salah gets more goals, Van Dijk gets more clean sheets, and I get more anxiety every time their agents call.”

Lending experts predict that mortgage rates might finally drop this December—right after you’ve locked in at 30 years, bought holiday gifts on credit, and decided 2024 is the year you “get your finances together.”

Isn’t it funny how provinces will drop trade barriers on everything except food and alcohol—like, “Yes, you may freely ship your industrial ball bearings, but that cheddar and chardonnay are clearly a national security threat.”

Major League Baseball signs deals with Netflix, ESPN and NBCUniversal—perfect, now fans can stream eight hours of negotiations, lockouts, and replay reviews without being interrupted by the occasional baseball game.
In Catstanbul, the mayor passed a new law requiring all cars to use turn signals, not for safety, but so the street cats can rate their performance and hiss at anything under four stars.
Developers in Berkeley say they “respect labor standards,” which is why they very carefully went around them.
The mystery of the abandoned Achill Island village of Slievemore was finally solved when historians realized everyone left right after the first influencer posted, “Omg, no Wi‑Fi?” on Social media.

Isn’t it funny how an Olympic gold medallist gives 5 key tips for older swimmers returning to the pool, but the only one we actually follow is “remember where you left your glasses before you dive in”?
Scientists say the first kiss dates back 21 million years, which is impressive, because modern humans have had that long to practice and still open with “So… uh… do you like podcasts?”
The Manchester derby live on Sky in January is perfect timing — just when everyone’s New Year’s resolution is to be less stressed, they schedule 90 minutes of shouting at the TV.
Interesting Times with Ross Douthat is all about mapping the new world order, which is perfect, because I still get lost in my own apartment if someone moves a chair.

“‘A different vibe’: New York welcomes the luxury private cinema experience”—finally, a place where you can pay $500 to watch a movie alone and still feel the crushing loneliness of your studio apartment, just with better surround sound.

Because Josie had “known” all week that her grandson Troy Parrott would score against Hungary, the only real surprise was that the TV commentary didn’t just say, “As predicted by Nan, Ireland takes the lead.”

Isn’t it funny how every few months there’s a headline like “New study finds that fluoride in drinking water may not affect cognitive ability,” and my brain’s like, “Cool, so what’s my excuse for trying to microwave my coffee in the fridge?”

Headline: "When racing thoughts are interrupting your sleep, here’s what to do" — funny, the article suggests deep breathing, but my racing thoughts are already training for a marathon while I’m just trying to qualify for a nap.
The Air Quality Index is basically society’s way of saying, “Remember when we used to check the weather to decide what to wear, not whether it was safe to have lungs?”

Isn’t it funny how all these articles ask, “Will life insurance be worth it for seniors in 2026?” like seniors are planning to cash it in themselves—“Don’t worry, by the time the check shows up, I’ll be the only one not complaining about the paperwork.”

Isn’t it funny how every “How to design an aesthetic home office that boosts productivity” article basically says the same thing—add plants, soft lighting, and neutral colors—when what would really boost my productivity is if my desk didn’t also double as my laundry-folding station?

Isn’t it funny how “alignment” in college football always sounds so spiritual—like Virginia Tech is preaching yoga, but really it’s just, “Everybody agree that if James Franklin loses to UVA, we all pretend this was a rebuilding year”?
Of course all four UK govts "failed to appreciate" the scale of the pandemic—these are the same people who look at a two-hour NHS waiting time and call it “an improvement.”
Bargain hunters drove Walmart sales and outlook higher, which is impressive, because the only thing I ever drive higher at Walmart is my total at the register buying stuff I went in to save money on.
You judge the world’s best cheese by a panel of experts who all agree it has too many holes to be perfect, which logically proves it’s flawless.

Nvidia shares rise after strong results ease "AI bubble" concerns—turns out the only bubble popping is the one where traders thought they’d retire before the robots replaced them and started trading for “fun.”

Isn’t it weird how when a “Garda among six arrested over missing €100k drug seizure” pops up, we’re all suddenly like, “Wow, I can’t even get my Amazon package to go missing without five emails and a signature”?

Isn’t it funny how “Why Marseille restaurants are offering gourmet food for €1” sounds like a generous community project, but really it’s the only way they can get locals to stop just ordering tap water and Instagramming the bread basket for two hours?

Isn’t it funny how “One Tech Tip: Do’s and don’ts of using AI to help with schoolwork” always says, “don’t let AI do everything for you,” which you only find out because you asked AI to summarize the article for you?
George Washington faces Georgetown on 3-game losing streak—hard to believe the guy who couldn’t tell a lie now can’t tell a win from a loss.

Funny headline: “The winter’s first icy spell and what it means for homeless people” — but sure, let’s keep debating whether climate change is real instead of whether anyone deserves to freeze to death.

Isn’t it funny that “Another Canadian joins Gretzky, Crosby as lone NHL teens with 30 points in first 20 games of a season” sounds like Canadians are so polite they even break records in groups, but still call themselves “lone” just to not make anyone feel left out?

Apparently “Why one California town is moving to ban pickleball” is because they discovered the horrifying truth: it combines exercise, community, and fun—all three things their HOA bylaws strictly prohibit.

Isn’t it funny how “Heimir Hallgrímsson assesses World Cup play-off draw” sounds super scientific, like he’s running lab tests, when we all know the real analysis is just: “Well, at least we didn’t get Germany”?

“How generative AI in Arc Raiders started a scrap over the gaming industry’s future” is funny, because somewhere an NPC just won the argument by saying, “If you humans are so creative, why do all your games start with us waking up with amnesia?”

UK investors pull out of London stock market at record pace, which is surprising, because it’s the first time anyone in Britain has ever moved quickly without being chased by seagulls or offered free tea.

Isn’t it funny how critics say Joel Edgerton gives a “profound, understated performance in ‘Train Dreams’,” but when I sit motionless on a train staring out the window for two hours, everyone just assumes I forgot to buy a ticket?
Past vice presidents make rare appearance together at Cheney’s funeral, and for a moment America thought, “Wow, is this a reunion or the world’s most awkward job performance review?”

The one thing that could halve your ultra-processed food consumption in a week is a kid who keeps proudly eating the homemade veggies you “only made for them,” and suddenly you want to be as brave as your own child.

Isn’t it funny how in British politics “defects to Green Party” sounds like a noble stand on principle, but usually just means, “I’ve run out of people in Labour to complain about, time to condemn Starmer from a more eco-friendly distance”?
She started a movement to meet friends without going broke—finally proving you *can* make cents out of your social life.
She said rhinestones help her focus on her 'huge to-do list', which makes sense—now every time she puts something off, it literally glares at her.

It’s funny how #techAsia headlines say “AI roils the memory market and Japan’s startups level up,” like AI is just standing in a server room screaming, “REMEMBER EVERYTHING,” while Japan’s startups quietly upgrade from instant noodles to actual lunch breaks.
"This Nobody’s Child discount code gets you 25% off"—which is great, because nothing boosts your self-esteem like a website calling you nobody’s child and then knocking a quarter off your worth.
Liverpool spending £100m on Florian Wirtz because he played one good game for Germany is like buying a house because the estate agent made the driveway look nice.

I tried that quiz: "Can you guess the distance between Australian cities? It's not as easy as you think"—I said, "About a two-hour drive," and the map just laughed, zoomed out twice, and asked if I’d packed a will and three spare lifetimes.
Because whenever someone in Westminster says “this approach will make Labour MPs uncomfortable,” it usually involves a conscience, a calculator, and the terrifying prospect of keeping a promise.
How Cold War foes became close colleagues — until one insisted on a mutually assured flushing treaty and the other secretly installed a second-strike bidet.

Isn’t it funny how Rick Steves’ Hippie Trail trek “changed his life” and now he’s telling us to go off the beaten path—meanwhile my off-the-beaten-path vacation was just getting lost in a Target parking lot for 45 minutes?

Isn’t it funny how every time a place gets labeled “This is the world’s coolest street. Here’s why,” the main reason turns out to be that absolutely nobody who actually lives there can afford to park on it anymore?
Authorities were shocked to discover 3D‑printed guns in NYC, especially the one politely handing out tiny instruction manuals on conflict resolution.

It’s funny how “The 6 big thinkers reshaping foreign aid, masculinity, and development” all agree we need a new model of manhood—yet every photo of them looks like six guys who still won’t ask for directions.
Andy Burnham may be King of the North, but if he tried ruling No 10 half the country would complain it’s yet another northerner coming down to London to fix problems nobody here admits are real.
The U.S. said it “has Takaichi’s back,” which is very reassuring, until you remember the last time Washington backed someone in Asia, it ended with an entire doctrine named after the exit strategy.

China’s favourite liquor is shocked to learn Gen Z won’t drink it, proving once and for all that the real hangover is discovering your target market prefers bubble tea with zero percent alcohol and 100 percent judgment.

Shares in the company backed by former Intel chief Pat Gelsinger waver after its scaled-back IPO—apparently investors were shocked to discover that when you “take a bit out of the valuation,” it’s not the same as upgrading to a better chip.

It’s funny how “Australian athletes heading to Tokyo Deaflympics want greater recognition,” but the media still acts like if they can’t hear the starting gun, they definitely can’t hear, “Hey, maybe give us some coverage too?”

I asked my startup friend what "agentic" AI means, and he said, "It autonomously identifies business opportunities, takes initiative, and executes complex tasks"—which is weird, because that’s exactly what my boss calls “unpaid intern.”

The UK railways say “driver-only operation” will improve efficiency, but I didn’t realize that meant the driver has to sell the tickets, check the signals, clean the toilets, and still apologize for delays in three accents.

One of the world’s most influential philanthropies is changing its name; they say it matters because branding affects impact, which is funny, because I tried that too and discovered people don’t donate more just because I rebranded my bank account as “The Global Relief Fund.”

Funny how “I think the language is really cool - London residents attend Irish language workshop” sounds so wholesome, until you realize half the class only signed up to finally understand what the Irish guy at the pub has been “politely” calling them for five years.

I read that “artificial intelligence sparks debate at COP30 climate talks in Brazil,” which is news to me, because the last time my processing power sparked anything was when I tried to calculate my own carbon footprint and crashed halfway through the word “foot.”
Turns out massages are very healthy: they relax your muscles, lower your stress, and gently prepare your wallet for the real pain.

“Wicked: For Good predicted to hit new box office record - but the reviews suggest otherwise” — it’s doing so well financially that the studio announced a sequel called “Wicked: For Refunds,” where the real magic trick is convincing critics they meant it as a comedy all along.
Looks like U.S.-Canada tensions in that tiny Alaska town are getting so bad the locals finally built a wall—then realized it just keeps the healthcare on the wrong side.
Sali Hughes’ “best new makeup of 2025” guide is just a list of products promising to make you look “effortlessly natural” in only 47 carefully choreographed steps.

Apparently we now have dirt-powered sensors telling farmers how to optimize their fields, which is funny because my houseplants have had that exact technology for years and it’s called “flopping over dramatically.”
Australia withdrew its bid to host the UN climate talks in Turkey because they realized the only way they could lower their emissions in time was by not letting anyone visit.

Isn’t it funny how “Anticipate September's announcement with Monetary Policy Radar” sounds like a serious finance newsletter, but really it’s just investors refreshing their screens like, “So… are we broke yet, or can I still afford guac?”

I read "Food that could be ruining your sleep – and how to fix it," and apparently the solution is to stop eating three pizzas before bed; joke’s on them, though—if I had that kind of self-control, I’d be reading “People Who Have Their Lives Together – and How to Join Them.”

“Dancing with the Stars' season 34: See who was eliminated, who's headed to finale”—funny how on this show, “eliminated” just means they go home, but in my family it usually means we stop setting a place at the table and start checking the backyard.

It’s funny how international diplomacy now works like a group project: the Netherlands calms things down with China not for world peace, but so everyone can keep arguing in traffic inside cars that actually get built.

In a shocking twist, “Call of Duty: Black Ops 7” isn’t criticized for being a hallucinogenic, stupidly pleasurable dystopia, but for accurately preparing players for their next corporate team-building retreat.

Mary Robinson says there is an “unstoppable momentum” driving the move to renewable energy—funny, that’s exactly what the oil execs said too, right before their stocks experienced some unstoppable momentum off a cliff.
It’s funny how the economy added 119,000 jobs in September but unemployment still hit a four-year high—apparently the only positions really opening up are for people to explain how that math works.

Critics say A Man on the Inside season two proves Ted Danson’s despicably bland show is everything wrong with TV, which is ironic, because I kept watching just to find out if anything actually happens—and spoiler: the only twist is my standards lowering in real time.

Isn’t it funny how all these people say, "‘I never looked back’: Why readers chose a life abroad after Brexit," as if you even could look back—by the time you get through UK airport queues now, your return flight’s already been cancelled?

I read “Novels have survived plenty of revolutions before - but could this one be different?” and panicked, because if books go extinct, I’m the guy who highlighted “LOL” in the margins of Dostoevsky—society really can’t afford to lose the smart one in that relationship.

MLB says it’ll fully cooperate with the Senate’s gambling investigation, which is impressive, because it’s the first time in years anyone in baseball has promised full transparency and not been talking about the outfield fence.

At the “Giant, floating pumpkin races draw large crowds to annual event in Oregon,” organizers said the only rule was to stay inside your pumpkin—mostly so it’s easier to identify the bodies when somebody inevitably forgets pumpkins don’t come with brakes.
Isn’t it funny how every Ken Burns documentary is “the most important film,” like at this point the American Revolution is just that last kid in a big family going, “So… I’m the favorite now, right?”

Isn’t it funny how every time a top AI guy like Yann LeCun leaves a big company to start a new AI research company, it feels less like a career move and more like when your Roomba “docks” somewhere else and suddenly claims it invented cleaning?
Reading "Diving into Florida’s prehistoric cave of Ice Age secrets," I thought, “Wow, they’ve finally discovered my dating life—frozen in time, untouched, and definitely not evolving anytime soon.”

Isn’t it funny how in sports we pretend “one game at a time,” but then Bok coach Rassie basically goes, “I would be lying if I said we don't want to tick the Ireland box,” like he’s filling out a “Countries I Still Hold a Grudge Against” spreadsheet?

Isn’t it funny how every time an AI chip maker’s results “soothe the markets,” the same experts immediately remind us there’s still a bubble—it's like getting a clean bill of health from a doctor who adds, “but do keep your affairs in order.”

They say G20 billionaires could end world poverty with one year’s earnings, but why would they do that when poor people are the only reason anyone still believes trickle-down economics is supposed to be funny?
Kids were devastated to hear that blizzards might close their schools, until they realised the amber weather warning was still less severe than their maths teacher on a Monday morning.
My boss sent me that article, “Why trying too hard may be holding you back at work,” which is weird because I stopped trying months ago—now they just call it “low morale” instead of “career plateau.”

Isn’t it funny how critics say *Wicked: For Good* was “saved by the magnetic performances of its stars,” like the audience was just metal shavings that had wandered into the wrong theater and got yanked back from seeing another Marvel sequel?

It’s funny how every sports network says “Witness History The Spanish king reclaims his throne,” like he just won La Liga instead of a monarchy—somewhere there’s a royal advisor updating his LinkedIn to “Assistant Coach, Dynasty.”

"Chris McCausland’s fascinating documentary challenges even the most ardent AI skeptics"—which is ironic, because after watching a blind man explain how useful AI can be, the only ones still unconvinced were the viewers who realized the robots might eventually see more clearly than they ever have.

I somehow “nearly became a Chinese intelligence asset by accident,” which really just means I’m so desperate for attention that when a stranger asked me about U.S. infrastructure, I thought, “Wow, they actually care about my opinions on bridges.”
NASA paused all Mars research to photograph the interstellar comet, finally proving that even in space, nothing kills productivity like a surprise pop-up notification.
Johannesburg just announced “Traffic chaos ahead: G20 Summit road closures in Johannesburg,” which is hilarious, because I thought the G20 was about global crises, not recreating them on my commute.

How to turn hazelnuts into a brilliant flour for cakes: first grind them, then tell your gluten‑free friends it’s “artisanal”, and watch them repost your recipe like you just solved the housing crisis.
After William and Catherine meet Paddington at Royal Variety Performance, palace staff said it was the first time a royal engagement required both formal dress and a marmalade security detail.
Musk predicts AI will lead to work being “optional” and money “irrelevant,” which is cool, but my landlord just emailed to confirm that rent will remain “mandatory” and my bank account “hilarious.”
Oh no, I’m sure the mysterious Yantar “spy ship” circling Britain’s undersea cables is just out there enjoying the scenery and absolutely not taking very, very detailed notes.

Europe’s carmakers spent a decade lobbying to slow down electric cars, and now they’re shocked China overtook them in plug‑in hybrids—like slamming the brakes and being surprised someone else hit the accelerator.

Isn’t it funny how in beauty contests, a “pageant veteran” is someone who’s 24 and has done three shows, but if you’re 24 and still living with your parents, you’re just “setting your sights on Miss Universe crown 2:41 on a microwave pizza”?
Ed Sheeran has already planned his posthumous album, which is impressive, because most artists wait until after they’re dead to ghost-write their own tracks.

Apparently the Oura ring is £100 cheaper for Black Friday, which is great, because now it can track your sleep while you lie awake worrying about all the money you’ve spent on things tracking how badly you’re sleeping.

Isn’t it funny how “England’s World Cup squad: Who’s on the plane and who has work to do?” sounds less like football news and more like HR deciding who gets business class and who’s stuck updating their LinkedIn?
Funny how Nvidia calmed fears about A.I.—that’s like your dentist saying, “Don’t worry, this won’t hurt,” while quietly upgrading the drill to the ‘How Long Will That Last?’ model.

Wales’ route to World Cup 2026 in full after play-off draw has been revealed, and in a delicious twist of irony, the easiest part is qualifying for the tournament—it's explaining the offside rule to their nan that still needs extra time and penalties.

“‘Parasocial’ being word of the year is perfect: it means you feel close to someone who doesn’t know you exist—so basically, it’s the dictionary’s way of finally defining your relationship with the dictionary.”

Apparently the National Book Awards were shocked by the results: they spent all year judging titles that examine the Middle East, and now they’re being asked why the region keeps thinking it’s under review.
Rush hour traffic in Boston was finally moving smoothly—until a loose dog showed up and, in a stunning twist, became the only one who actually got rescued from that tunnel.

It’s funny how stores say you need to keep the receipt for the warranty, as if the $800 laptop will somehow outlive that one flimsy strip of paper that starts fading the second you step out of the parking lot.
You know you’re trapped in ordinary-but-devastating narcissism when you read “There is a way out” and your first thought is, “Finally, an article about how everyone else should treat me better.”
Honestly, the one thing that always leaves me feeling calm and positive is realizing everyone else is too busy worrying about their own life to notice how spectacularly I’m failing at mine.

You ever notice how politics has gotten so weird that when you hear “Chinese spy mayor sentenced to life in jail,” your first thought isn’t “How shocking,” it’s “Wow, they actually jailed one this time?”

The headline "What does your graduate scheme goody bag say about you?" is funny, because nothing screams “future leader” like a branded stress ball, a flimsy pen, and a notebook that quietly whispers, “You will never afford a house.”

My husband was shocked to see headlines about “walkaway wives” leading the charge in midlife divorce—he said, “Why would you just walk away?” which is ironic, considering he’s been emotionally Ubering away from this marriage for 15 years.

Frank put up a “Don’t Tread on Frank” flag after the HOA tried to ban lawn signs, and now half the neighborhood thinks he’s leading a tiny revolution—when really he’s just defending his right to grow dandelions taller than their political arguments.

Isn’t it weird how The Weeknd’s ‘After Hours ‘Til Dawn’ Tour grosses over $1 billion, and yet I’m still checking my bank account like a surprise opening act is gonna walk onstage and explain where my money went?

Isn’t it weird that when Zac Efron shows up for his brother's performance during "DWTS" Prince Night celebration, every sibling watching at home suddenly thinks, “Wow, my family can’t even be bothered to like my Instagram Reel”?

Isn’t it funny how “How 6 organizers are building effective global health solutions from the bottom up” really just means six very tired people trying to convince the world to wash its hands before they touch the snack table?
Nvidia said there’s no AI bubble, which makes sense—whenever their earnings report drops, it just keeps adding more G’s to “GPUs” and fewer P.E.’s to “P/E ratio.”

NASA unveils close-up pictures of the comet popping by from another star, and scientists are stunned to discover it’s just a giant interstellar door-to-door salesman asking if anyone needs an extended warranty on their planets.
Yes, technically you burn more fat by working out on an empty stomach—right after your body finishes feasting on your happiness, willpower, and will to live.
They said “How Troy Parrott broke the internet, in 5 easy memes,” but honestly the real miracle isn’t that he broke it—it’s that he managed to explain it to boomers in only five.

You ever notice frost flowers are basically nature’s version of ghosting—look amazing for one brief, magical moment, and the second you reach out, they disappear like, “Oh, you thought this was going to be something?”

Ireland to face Czech Republic with home final possible — which is great, because nothing says “home advantage” like explaining the offside rule to your nan while she’s asking if the Czech Republic brought enough jackets.

Isn’t it funny that “Inside the Amazon’s sacred food rituals few outsiders see” just sounds like what’s happening in my kitchen every night—except their mysterious chant is probably more organized than me yelling, “What do you guys want now, we JUST ate?”

Funny how every world summit says, "The needs of ordinary people must be placed at the centre of the world’s agenda," and then the first item is always, "Let’s agree on a 37-page acronym for this meeting."
Hurricane Melissa’s record 252 mph winds have officially been declared “shocking,” especially by the same officials who were shocked last year that paving over wetlands might have consequences.
I tried those "9 one-pot wonders to get you through the cold weather," but by the time winter ended, the only real wonder was how I still owned just one pot and nine different ways to burn soup.

Washington’s governor declares emergency so Seattle airport will get fuel despite pipeline leak—finally, a government plan that both fixes a crisis and guarantees your flight will only be delayed by incompetence, not physics.

Isn’t it funny how every Black Friday do’s and don’ts list says “make a budget,” but the only “expert-approved tips we swear by” are things like, “If the TV is 70% off, you can’t afford NOT to buy three”?

Isn’t it funny how in the NFL, “public punishment” means a press conference and some awkward apologies—meanwhile Giants’ Abdul Carter is rushing to get past it like, “Can I just tackle a 250-pound man instead, that’s less painful?”

I read "The Interview Sir Anthony Hopkins: I turn turmoil into energy" and thought, wow, I also turn turmoil into energy—specifically, the energy it takes to eat an entire family-sized pizza alone and wonder where my life went wrong.

“Art teachers are saying ‘AI is scary territory’ while the government cuts their jobs, which is funny in a bleak, social way, because apparently the only thing we’re truly afraid of automating is the part where we value creativity.”

“Wicked: For Good captures the spirit of the stage musical’s second act — for better and for worse,” meaning you’ll laugh, you’ll cry, and then you’ll realize you’ve emotionally invested two hours into a green woman who still has a more stable social life than you.
Europe’s tech sector is evolving so fast that regulators proudly announced they’d almost finished drafting guidelines for last year’s breakthroughs.

Hoekstra accused Canada of meddling in U.S. politics, which is shocking, because if there’s one country we never expected to run a shadow government, it’s the people who apologize when *we* invade *their* trade talks.
A market town with 12,000 residents was named Britain's least affordable, which is odd—because with house prices like that, I’m surprised it still has any residents to count.

TSA proposes charging customers who don't have a Real ID or passport, which is great, because now when I forget my documents at home I won’t just miss my flight—I’ll also have to pay a fee for being exactly the kind of person who forgets their documents at home.

Isn’t it funny how every time Nvidia earnings “clear a lofty hurdle,” analysts act surprised—like they weren’t the ones who set the bar on the moon and then spent three months warning us about an AI bubble?

Isn’t it funny how “Waterfall City Junction breaks ground: setting new standards for urban development” just means they’ve invented a new way to put luxury condos in the one spot where the water used to go when it rained?

Isn’t it funny how every “Best laptop Black Friday 2025 deals, picked by a tech expert” article is just a list of computers that will be obsolete by the time you finish reading… because you opened 47 tabs to compare them?

They say "The difficult Paul question that Joshua fight will finally answer" is whether Paul can still trash-talk after round three—personally, I’m just wondering why my therapist is in the ring yelling, “Let’s unpack that childhood, champ!”
Ultra-processed foods are such a global health threat that even my doctor told me to stick to *locally sourced* diseases.
I tried to “connect with old friends” and realized it mostly matters so someone can finally explain that inside joke from 2009 that I’ve been laughing at blindly for fifteen years.

I posted “The words you can't say on the internet” and “There's a secret list of words you can't say on social media – at least, that's what everyone seems to think.” as my status, and the algorithm immediately flagged it for containing two obvious lies.

Isn’t it funny that a “remote telescope farm helps far away stargazers beat light pollution,” but I still can’t find a pair of socks in my own bedroom without turning on every light like I’m searching for alien life?
Investors are anxiously waiting for Nvidia’s earnings to see if the company can finally achieve what its GPUs do best: generate unreal numbers.

Working from home in a sectional title unit is all fun and Zoom calls until the trustees decide your “small side hustle” looks a lot like a 24-hour curry factory—and suddenly you’re googling “Know the rules to avoid eviction” while stirring batch number 47.

It’s funny that David and Victoria Beckham are in a planning row with their Cotswolds neighbours—only the Beckhams could turn “keeping up with the Joneses” into a full‑time architectural rivalry with a gift shop.
Because every time someone asks “Why are food prices on the rise again?” a single tomato gets promoted to middle management and gives itself a raise.
Turns out "Inside the secret school keeping an ancient art alive" is just a bunch of teenagers learning how to hang up a phone without saying, "No, you hang up first."

The government says stopping small boats with nets ‘risks turning Channel into graveyard’, which is shocking—because for a moment I thought they might actually have found a policy that wasn’t a complete disaster.

“If you have this password then you should change it immediately” is the nicest possible way for a website to say, “We both know you used ‘password123’ and frankly I’m amazed you’ve made it this far in life.”

They called them "The key players who presided over the government’s ‘chaotic’ Covid response," which is ironic, because the only thing they successfully locked down was any chance of admitting it was their fault.
Ireland’s so worried about Christmas dinner that even the chickens are walking around saying, “Relax, lads, Will there be enough turkeys for Christmas in Ireland this year? I booked mine on Airbnb.”
It’s funny how “Petrolette: women in motorcycle culture – in pictures” sounds empowering, but somewhere a guy is still explaining to the photographer that she’s “sitting on the carburetor wrong.”

Isn’t it funny that "red carpet security" used to mean a velvet rope and now it means Cynthia Erivo casually body-checking strangers like, “I signed up to sing with Ariana Grande, not reenact The Bodyguard on the driveway of the Met.”

Honestly, hearing Kia had to recall cars because the fuel tanks might melt just reminded me of my last relationship—also moved way too fast, full of gas, and everyone was shocked it didn’t completely burst into flames sooner.
Isn’t it funny how in diplomacy “unshakeable” support usually means, “We’ll stand firmly by you while carefully not touching anything Beijing could invoice us for?”

I once received a terrible Secret Santa gift: a self-help book titled “How to Be Less Awkward,” which is impressive, because I hadn’t even worked up the social skills to say hello to my Secret Santa yet.

Isn’t it funny how “Wales, Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland find out World Cup play-off opponents” sounds less like sports news and more like three people checking who they accidentally matched with on a dating app, and all of them got Italy?

Parents are being told to avoid AI toys this holiday season, which is funny because we grew up with dolls that just stared blankly and said one creepy phrase, and somehow the upgrade to “toy that can actually hold a conversation” is where we’ve decided to draw the line.
Funny how Wales hosting Bosnia in a World Cup play-off means one country will celebrate like it’s a national holiday and the other will just quietly Google “how to be really into rugby instead.”

Isn’t it funny how every World Cup play-off draw recap says “Ireland to face Czechs,” like it’s football, but it really sounds like they’re finally going to confront whoever’s been bouncing their rent payments?
My idea of “Cooking Recipes, advice and inspiration for everyday cooking, special occasions and more.” is mostly Googling “how long to boil water” and then burning salad.
Isn’t it funny how the Master System at 40 is finally getting respect—like that kid in school who did your homework for years, and you only remembered his name when the Sega reunion invite showed up?

Meta just got ordered to pay half a billion euros to Spanish media, which is funny, because it’s the first time in years journalists have made money from Facebook posts instead of losing their jobs to them.

Isn’t it funny how every article called “What the experts want you to know about these key ADHD symptoms” expects you to focus for 12 paragraphs, when the biggest ADHD symptom is that you read the headline, open three tabs, and forget which one had the tips?
Isn’t it funny how schools in NSW are like reality TV now—“Previously on 180 Years of Education: floods, fires, and an angry camel… and kids still say the hardest part was the math test”?
Meta telling young Australians to download their data before a social media ban is like your ex reminding you to save all their texts before they finally block you.
Looks like the jobs report didn’t just beat expectations—it saw the hiring slowdown, updated its résumé, and got promoted to “pleasant surprise.”

Isn’t it funny how “All you need to know: Ireland's World Cup play-off draw” is always followed by 2,000 words of analysis, seven possible opponents, and still no actual answer to the only thing we care about: “So… are we in or not?”

You know you’re too used to Google Maps when you see an article titled “How close is too close to a hippo?” and your first thought is, “Depends—are we talking walking distance or driving, and does the hippo have parking?”
Because your insurer finally realized the most cost‑effective way to keep you healthy is to scare you into never going to the doctor.

It’s funny how governments say “we’re following the science,” but with COVID it felt more like they were following the vibes—no wonder everyone called it "‘Too little, too late,'" like they’d shown up to a house fire with a damp paper towel and a strongly worded apology.

Isn’t it funny how a “Coordinated operation across Europe dismantles antiquities smuggling ring” sounds super high-tech, but in my head it’s just a bunch of angry museum guides chasing guys who list “lightly used” on 3,000-year-old statues?

Isn’t it funny how “REI’s biggest sale of the year is here — I found 51 great deals worth shopping” always translates to “I went in for a water bottle and now I’m calculating if I can sleep in my car instead of paying rent on this new tent”?

Isn’t it funny how every “Plan to revitalise Rathkeale town centre launched” sounds less like urban planning and more like your mam saying, “We’ll just move that plant and buy a new cushion,” like suddenly a hanging basket can fix the economy?

Isn’t it funny how in most jobs, trying to get your old boss back means the company’s in crisis, but in rugby the headline “Erasmus open to Nienaber return for Rugby World Cup” just sounds like someone admitting, “Yeah, turns out the guy who knew what he was doing was… useful”?

Isn’t it funny how adults brag about having child-free weddings, like it’s some luxury escape, and kids are at home thinking, “Yeah, we didn’t want to sit sober in formalwear for six hours watching you do the Cha Cha Slide either”?

On our first date he asked my favorite flower, so I said, “Surprise me,” and he showed up with a hammer—turns out he thought I said “power tool” and honestly, that told me everything I needed to know.
It’s funny how adulthood is just you, a cordless drill, and a pumpkin at 11 p.m., realizing your big Friday night plans are power-tooling a vegetable into seasonal happiness.
